title: War in the Middle East: Beyond the clash of arms
summary: The history of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict shows that military victories have never been a substitute for a lack of vision, which is now more glaring than ever.

title: Lebanon says over 100 killed in new Israeli strikes
summary: The health ministry, in a revised toll issued late Sunday, put the total killed in the new strikes at 105 and 359 wounded.

title: Thierry Breton to 'Le Monde': 'France's voice is less powerful' in Europe
summary: France's former European commissioner sees a 'drift' in Germany's growing influence in EU institutions. 'Europe is about balance, serving the general European interest, not the interests of a single country. If we upset this balance, the European project is in danger,' he warns.

title: Doctors face challenge of identifying chemical submission in cases of sexual violence
summary: The French mass rape trial is calling into question the role of doctors, family doctors in particular, who are poorly trained to deal with a phenomenon that is difficult to identify.

title: How sex trafficking allegations against P. Diddy are being exploited to smear Kamala Harris
summary: MAGA communities and Donald Trump himself have seized on the sex trafficking accusations made against the rapper to try and implicate Kamala Harris, through posting fake images.

title: In China, the world's oldest cheese reveals its secrets 3,600 years later
summary: Chinese researchers have extracted and analyzed the DNA of pieces of kefir from cow and goat found in a 3,600-year-old tomb. The samples may reveal more about the origins of this fermented cheese.

title: In China, the world's oldest cheese reveals its secrets 3,600 years later
summary: Chinese researchers have extracted and analyzed the DNA of pieces of kefir from cow and goat found in a 3,600-year-old tomb. The samples may reveal more about the origins of this fermented cheese.

title: Austria's far-right Freedom Party and its historical national election win
summary: Herbert Kickl, a former interior minister and longtime campaign strategist, has led the Freedom Party since 2021. As Austria's new leader however, he needs a coalition partner to command a parliamentary majority. Rivals have said they won’t work with Kickl in government.

title: Why Stellantis is bringing Chinese carmaker Leapmotor to Europe
summary: In exchange for access to the European market, the vehicle manufacturer is making its technology available to the Franco-American-Italian group.

title: Beirut reels after Hassan Nasrallah's violent death
summary: In the Shiite neighborhood of Khandak Al-Ghamik, residents are grappling with a mix of anger and a sense of abandonment. The violence of the Hezbollah leader's death has sent shockwaves beyond the Shiite community.

title: What exactly is a French president's 'reserved domain'?
summary: This notion, elaborated in 1959, refers to matters in which the president is supposed to be the sole decision-maker – though it has no constitutional basis.

title: 4 reasons to go to Brooklyn if you like Paul Auster
summary: Follow in the footsteps of the 'New York Trilogy' author in this part of the metropolis, where he lived in a brownstone, a typical red sandstone house.

title: A spiral dive into Surrealism at the Centre Pompidou
summary: A vast and rich exhibition at the Centre Pompidou in Paris reveals a new history of the movement launched 100 years ago, but not without a few omissions and blunders.

title: In Austria, migration dominates the general election campaign
summary: The Alpine country is one of the countries which receives the most refugees per capita in the EU. But the far right, now leading in the polls, is promising to 'stop the right of asylum' and brandishing the racist theory of the 'great replacement.'

title: Who are Russia's 'illegal' spies?
summary: Secret agents in Russia's 'illegals' program, launched during the 1930s under Stalin,  live under elaborate false identities for many years. Le Monde tells the story of two of these spies who were recently unmasked.

title: French mass rape trial: Defendants claim they didn't 'intend' to rape Gisèle Pelicot
summary: Nine of Dominique Pelicot's 50 co-defendants have testified. They all put forward the same defense, claiming that they had been 'manipulated' and did not realize that the victim was unconscious due to the drugs her husband was secretly administering.

title: Why Russia has decided to review its nuclear doctrine
summary: After having limited himself to making threats since the war in Ukraine started, Vladimir Putin wants to formally broaden the conditions for the use of his atomic arsenal. The announcement comes as a response to Ukrainian attacks carried out deep inside Russia.

title: French mass rape trial also takes place outside the courtroom
summary: Since the trial began on September 2, it has had an unusual atmosphere. Every day, Gisèle Pelicot enters the Avignon courthouse to the applause of dozens of people.

title: Iran faces a dilemma in the wake of Hassan Nasrallah's death
summary: For months now, Tehran has been suffering a series of setbacks inflicted by Israel without being able to retaliate. The Islamist regime may have to resort to using the nuclear threat once again.

title: At least 93 people were killed in the wake of Hurricane Helene, millions without power as bridges wash away in North Carolina
summary: Helene hit Florida's northern Gulf shore as a Category 4 hurricane with winds of 140 miles per hour, leaving catastrophic damage across several states. Flash flood warnings remain in effect in parts of western North Carolina, with thousands still seeking assistance Red Cross shelters.

title: Country legend Kris Kristofferson, co-writer of 'Me and Bobby McGee,' has died at age 88
summary: The actor and musician, who starred in the original 'A Star is Born' in 1976, formed the supergroup The Highwaymen in the mid-1980s with Johnny Cash, Waylon Jennings and Willie Nelson.

title: 'In China, most billionaires have either undergone some kind of refashioning or taken steps to avoid the limelight'
summary: The Chinese authorities have brought several social media personalities to heel, particularly on Douyin, the Chinese version of TikTok, explains Beijing correspondent Harold Thibault.

title: Why Le Pen and 26 other far-right party members are standing trial in Paris in fake EU Parliament jobs case
summary: Twenty-seven defendants are going on trial from Monday on suspicion of embezzling several million euros of European funds.

title: The terrible cost to Israel of marginalizing the PLO
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is waging a relentless war against opponents who only emerged as a result of the weakening of the Palestine Liberation Organization, expelled from Lebanon by Israel to the benefit of Hezbollah and marginalized in Gaza, which has become a Hamas stronghold.

title: Austria's far right achieves highest election result since 1945
summary: With 28.8% of the vote in Sunday's parliamentary elections, Austria's Freedom Party victory has triggered a political earthquake in the country of 9 million inhabitants. But all the other parties still refuse to form a coalition with them.

title: Hamas says its leader in Lebanon killed in air strike
summary: The Palestinian militant group reports that Fatah Sharif Abu al-Amine died in a strike on the El-Buss refugee camp near the southern city of Tyre.

title: California Governor Gavin Newsom vetoes AI safety bill
summary: The legislation makes artificial intelligence companies legally liable for damage caused by their models.

title: Le Pen and allies go on trial over fake job system to finance party with EU funds
summary: Numerous figures from Marine Le Pen's far-right party will be sitting on the defendant's bench in the Paris criminal court from Monday, as they go on trial for misappropriating funds supposed to pay for staffers of members of the European Parliament.

title: France's Antoine Griezmann retires from international football
summary: With 137 appearances and 44 goals, the Atletico Madrid forward is the third most-capped player and fourth-highest goalscorer in France's history.

title: Main accused again absent from French mass rape trial
summary: Accused of raping and recruiting many strangers to rape his sedated wife, Dominique Pelicot was not present in court on Monday as he must undergo medical treatment, reported the presiding judge.

title: France's new interior minister wants immigration referendum
summary: Bruno Retailleau said he regretted that such a referendum was not currently possible under the Constitution.

title: Boris Johnson claims in memoir Emmanuel Macron wanted to 'punish' Britain for Brexit
summary: In excerpts from his memoir, the former British prime minister describes the French president as a 'positive nuisance' during Brexit negotiations.

title: Hezbollah will select new chief 'at earliest opportunity'
summary: Speaking in a televised broadcast on Monday, Hezbollah's deputy leader Naim Qassem did not specify when the selection would take place or when Hassan Nasrallah's funeral would be held.

title: US continues to back Israeli military operations, even when blindsided
summary: The American administration, whose action is limited, is strengthening its presence in the eastern Mediterranean. After the elimination of the Hezbollah leader, its main concern is Iran and the issue of nuclear weapons.

title: In the Arab world, split reactions to Nasrallah killing reflect Hezbollah's divisiveness
summary: In the Middle East, Hassan Nasrallah was as much appreciated for his ability to stand up to Israel as he was reviled for his involvement in crushing the Syrian revolution and pandering to Iranian interests.

title: In Nepal, torrential rains devastate Kathmandu and its valley
summary: The Nepalese capital and its densely urbanized valley have borne the brunt of the floods and landslides that have ravaged the central and eastern parts of the small Himalayan country.

title: In Moscow, metro booths seek to attract new volunteers for the Ukrainian front
summary: In the past month, new informational booths have popped up between the escalators and the turnstiles. Passengers are being offered the equivalent of €50,000 to join the army, an incentive that has met with limited success.
